pygissim package

Submodules

pygissim.engine module

engine.py

These classes and functions are the building blocks for simulating a compute system. They are grouped in this file by function: (general, network, compute, queue, work)

class pygissim.engine.BalancingModel(*values)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enumeration of ways requests can be balanced across multiple ComputeNodes in a ServiceProvider.

CONTAINERIZED = 'containerized'
FAILOVER = 'failover'
OTHER = 'other'
ROUND_ROBIN = 'roundrobin'
SINGLE = '1'
classmethod from_str(value: str) → BalancingModel[source]

Convenience method for constructing BalancingModels from a string representation.

Parameters:

value – The string representation.

Returns:

The BalancingModel. Returns OTHER if the string is not a recognized type.

Return type:

BalancingModel

class pygissim.engine.ClientRequest(name: str, desc: str, wf_name: str, request_clock: int, solution: ClientRequestSolution, tx_id: int)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a single request originating from a configured Workflow. ClientRequests are created by the simulator, so not usually created by other means.

Parameters:

  • name – Usually auto-generated by next_name

  • desc – Additional descriptive text. Usually empty.

  • wf_name – The name of the workflow that caused this request.

  • request_clock – The simulation time when the request was created.

  • solution – The ClientRequestSolution that defines the work to be done.

  • tx_id – A Workflow execution can create a set of ClientRequests. This is the Transaction id.

is_finished() → bool[source]

Convenience function.

Returns:

True if the ClientRequestSolution solution is finished.

classmethod next_id() → int[source]

Increments and returns the next in a sequence of numbers.

classmethod next_name() → str[source]

Creates a new unique name based on next_id

summary_metric() → RequestMetric[source]

A ClientRequest accumulates a metric after every step.

Returns:

A single RequestMetric that sums all of the accumulated metrics to date.

class pygissim.engine.ClientRequestSolution(steps: list[ClientRequestSolutionStep] | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

When a Workflow is executed, a ClientRequestSolution is created for each WorkflowChain. The solution is then assigned to the ClientRequest.

A ClientRequestSolution is processed one step at a time. As steps are finished, they are popped off the front of the list. The solution is finished when there are no more steps to complete.

current_step() → ClientRequestSolutionStep | None[source]
Returns:

The first step in the remainder. Returns None if no steps remain.

goto_next_step()[source]

Pops the first step off the remaining steps.

is_finished() → bool[source]
Returns:

True if list of steps is empty.

class pygissim.engine.ComputeNode(name: str, desc: str, hw_def: HardwareDef, memory_GB: int, zone: Zone, type: ComputeNodeType)[source]

Bases: ServiceTimeCalculator

Represents a computing resource that has a HardwareDef and exists in a network Zone.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive name. Should be unique in a pygissim.pygissim.Design.

  • desc – Additional descriptive text.

  • hw_def – The hardware definition of the ComputeNode. Determines its performance.

  • memory_GB – Configured memory in gigabytes (GB). Is mostly used for determining overallocation of physical host memory on virtual hosts.

  • zone – The network Zone that the ComputeNode is connected to.

  • type – The type of ComputeNode.

add_virtual_host(name: str, v_cores: int, memory_GB: int)[source]

Creates and adds a virtual ComputeNode to a physical server.

Raises:

TypeError – if this is not a physical server.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive string. Should be unique in a Design.

  • v_cores – The number of virtual cores assigned to this virtual machine.

  • memory_GB – The amount of memory in gigabytes (GB) assigned to this virtual machine.

adjusted_service_time(st: int) → int[source]

The relative performance of this ComputeNode will affect the service times. All service times in WorkflowDefStep are based on the baseline per core performance defined in HardwareDef. The hardware definition of this node may be faster or slower than that baseline and will make the calculated service times shorter or longer, respectively.

Parameters:

st – The input baseline service time in milliseconds (ms).

Returns:

The adjusted service time in milliseconds (ms).

calculate_latency(request) → int | None[source]
Parameters:

request – The ClientRequest whose current step needs a latency time calculation.

Returns:

None. Only Connections have latency.

calculate_service_time(request: ClientRequest) → int | None[source]
Parameters:

request – The ClientRequest whose current step needs a service time calculation.

Returns:

The service time in milliseconds (ms). Returns None if there is no current step.

provide_queue() → MultiQueue[source]

Creates and returns a MultiQueue that represent’s this ComputeNode’s ability to do work. This includes a number of ‘channels’ (slots for processing requests in parallel) and a main queue where requests will wait until there is an available channel.

For a ComputeNode, the channel count will generally be the number of cores (virtual or physical). Client nodes are the exception, because they represent the compute for a group of users. The channel count for them is an arbitrarily large number.

remove_virtual_host(v_host: ComputeNode)[source]

Removes a virtual machine from the list on this physical server.

Parameters:

v_host – The virtual machine to remove.

set_vcore_count(count: int)[source]
Parameters:

count – Sets the number of virtual cores assigned to this virtual machine. Will be ignored if not a virtual host.

specint_rate2017_per_core() → float[source]

Per-core performance of the hardware. Including threading factor.

total_cpu_allocation() → int[source]
Returns:

The sum of all virtual host virtual core allocations accounting for hyperthreading.

total_memory_allocation() → int[source]
Returns:

The sum of all virtual host memory allocations.

total_vcpu_allocation() → int[source]
Returns:

The sum of all virtual host virtual core allocations.

vcore_count() → int[source]
Returns:

The number of virtual cores assigned to a virtual machine. Will be zero if this ComputeNode is not a virtual host.

virtual_host(index: int) → ComputeNode | None[source]
Parameters:

index – The ordered index of the virtual host to return.

Returns:

The virtual host at the index. Returns None if the index is invalid.

Return type:

Optional[ComputeNode]

virtual_host_count() → int[source]
Returns:

The count of virtual hosts on this ComputeNode.

class pygissim.engine.Connection(source: Zone, dest: Zone, bw: int = 1000, lat: int = 0)[source]

Bases: ServiceTimeCalculator

Represents a one-way link between Zones. The source and destination Zone may be the same. To connect Zones for two-way communication, there needs to be two Connections, upstream and downstream.

Parameters:

  • source (Zone) – The upstream Zone. Information flows from the source.

  • dest (Zone) – The downstream Zone. Information flows to the destination.

  • bw (int) – The stated bandwidth of the connection in megabits per second (Mbps).

  • lat (int) – The average latency of the connection in milliseconds (ms).

calculate_latency(request) → int | None[source]

Calculates the latency time for the ClientRequest’s current step in this Connection. This is the chatter of the current step times the latency of this Connection.

Parameters:

request (ClientRequest) – The ClientRequest being transmitted over this Connection.

Returns:

The number of milliseconds of latency for the current step. Is None if the current step is None.

Return type:

Optional[int]

calculate_service_time(request: ClientRequest) → int | None[source]

Calculates the service time for the ClientRequest’s current step in this Connection. This takes the data size and determines how many milliseconds it would take to transmit.

Parameters:

request (ClientRequest) – The ClientRequest being transmitted over this Connection.

Returns:

The number of milliseconds to transmit the current step. Is None if the current step is None.

Return type:

Optional[int]

description() → str[source]

Describes the Connection using the namesx of the source and destination Zones.

Example: ‘Zone A to Zone B’

inverted() → Connection[source]

Inverts the Connection and returns it.

Returns:

A copy of the Connection with the source and destination swapped.

Return type:

Connection

is_local() → bool[source]

Indication that the Connection’s source and destination are the same Zone.

Returns:

True if the source and destination Zone are equal.

Return type:

bool

provide_queue() → MultiQueue[source]

A ServiceTimeCalculator provides a MultiQueue to the pygissim.pygissim.Simulator.

Returns:

A queue for handling ClientRequests.

Return type:

MultiQueue

class pygissim.engine.MultiQueue(st_calculator: ServiceTimeCalculator, wait_mode: WaitMode, channel_count: int)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a queue with one or more channels of parallel processing and a single queue used when waiting for a turn in a channel.

Analogy: Multiple bank tellers (channels) and a queue waiting to see a teller.

The number of channels will be determined by the service time calculator.

  • Connection: 2 channels

  • ComputeNode: the number of cores (physical host or client) or virtual cores (virtual host)

Parameters:

  • st_calculator – The Connection or ComputeNode that is designated to calculate all service times for this MultiQueue.

  • wait_mode – Will be TRANSMITTING for Connections and PROCESSING for ComputeNodes

  • channel_count – The number of channels that this MultiQueue will have.

all_waiting_requests() → list[WaitingRequest][source]
Returns:

A list of all waiting requests in channels and in the main queue.

available_channel_count() → int[source]
Returns:

The number of channels without any active requests in them.

channels_with_finished_requests(clock: int) → list[int][source]
Parameters:

clock – The current simulation time.

Returns:

A list of channel indexes with requests in them that have finished processing.

channels_with_requests() → list[int][source]
Returns:

A list of channel indexes with active requests in them.

enqueue(request: ClientRequest, clock: int)[source]

Wraps the request in a WaitingRequest. If there are available channels, the request will be put in it and immediately start processing. If there are no channels available, the request is added to the end of the main queue.

Parameters:

  • request – The request that needs to be processed by this queue’s service time calculator.

  • clock – The current simulation time.

first_available_channel() → int | None[source]
Returns:

The index of the first available channel. Returns None if all channels are occupied.

Return type:

Optional[int]

get_performance_metric(clock: int) → QueueMetric[source]
Returns:

A performance metric for the queue indicating how busy it is.

name() → str[source]
Returns:

The name of the service time calculator (i.e. the Connection or ComputeNode)

next_event_time() → int | None[source]
Returns:

The simulation clock when the next request in a channel will be finished. Returns None if no requests being processed.

remove_finished_requests(clock: int) → list[Tuple[ClientRequest, RequestMetric]][source]

The simulation clock has moved forward and any waiting requests whose wait_end has arrived need to move on.

ClientRequests are unwrapped and returned, along with metrics about how long they waited.

Any open channels are filled with requests from the main queue, if any are waiting.

Parameters:

clock – The current simulation time.

Returns:

A list of all requests that have finished this step and need to move on and their metrics.

Return type:

Tuple[ClientRequest, RequestMetric]

request_count() → int[source]
Returns:

The total count of requests in channels and in the main queue.

class pygissim.engine.QueueMetric(source: str, stc_type: str, clock: int, channel_count: int, request_count: int)[source]

Bases: object

Read-only data class for tracking the utilization rate of all queues (compute and network)

Parameters:

  • source (str) – The name of the MultiQueue that was measured.

  • stc_type (str) – The type of the MultiQueue’s ServiceTimeCalculator’.

  • clock (int) – The simulation time (in ms) when the measurement was taken.

  • channel_count (int) – The number of parallel channels in the MultiQueue.

  • request_count – The number of requests being processed and queued.

channel_count: int
clock: int
request_count: int
source: str
stc_type: str
utilization() → float[source]

Utility function to return the utilization of a network connection or a compute node.

  • Channels represents the number of parallel channels to do work. If they are all full, then 1.0 is returned (100%)

  • If all channels are full and more requests were waiting, then the result will be more than 1.0 (> 100%)

class pygissim.engine.RequestMetric(source: str, clock: int, request_name: str, workflow_name: str, service_time: int, queue_time: int, latency_time: int)[source]

Bases: object

DataClass for tracking the utilization rate of all queues (compute and network). A RequestMetric is reported every time a ClientRequest leaves a MultiQueue. The time values represent the service time, queue time and latency time the ClientRequest experienced between being enqueued and completed.

Parameters:

  • source (str) – The name of the MultiQueue that was measured.

  • clock (int) – The simulation time (in ms) when the measurement was taken.

  • request_name (str) – The name of the ClientRequest.

  • workflow_name (str) – The name of the Workflow.

  • service_time (int) – The time spent processing the ClientRequest (in ms).

  • queue_time (int) – The time spent in queue (in ms).

  • latency_time (int) – The time spent in latency (in ms).

clock: int
latency_time: int
queue_time: int
request_name: str
service_time: int
source: str
workflow_name: str

class pygissim.engine.ServiceProvider(name: str, desc: str, service: ServiceDef, nodes: list[ComputeNode])[source]

Bases: object

Represents one or more ComputeNodes that are assigned to handle a particular service type.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive name. Should be unique in a Design.

  • desc – Additional descriptive text.

  • service – The definition of the service that this provides.

  • nodes – The list of ComputeNodes that will handle the service requests.

add_node(node: ComputeNode)[source]

Adds a ComputeNode to the list that handle service requests. Will be ignored if the BalancingModel does not support additional nodes.

  • Example: BalancingModel SINGLE and there already is a node.

  • Example: BalancingModel FAILOVER and there already are two nodes.

Parameters:

node – The ComputeNode to add.

handler_node() → ComputeNode | None[source]

For a ServiceProvider with a service BalancingModel of ROUND_ROBIN, the primary will rotate every time this is called.

Returns:

The ComputeNode that is currently the primary. Returns None if there are no nodes assigned.

Return type:

Optional[ComputeNode]

class pygissim.engine.ServiceTimeCalculator[source]

Bases: ABC

Abstract base class for classes that will be delegates for a MultiQueue to calculate service time and latency time. The two subclasses are Connection and ComputeNode.

abstractmethod calculate_latency(request: ClientRequest) → int[source]
abstractmethod calculate_service_time(request: ClientRequest) → int[source]
abstractmethod provide_queue() → MultiQueue[source]
class pygissim.engine.ThreadingModel(*values)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enumeration of threading models. Physical represents 1:1 threads to cores. Hyperthreaded represents 2:1 threads to cores. Used for ComputeNode service time calculation.

HYPERTHREADED = 'ht'
PHYSICAL = 'physical'
factor() → float[source]

The factor applied to the per-core performace for ComputeNodes.

class pygissim.engine.WaitMode(*values)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enumeration of the potential states of a WaitingRequest.

PROCESSING = 'processing'
QUEUEING = 'queueing'
TRANSMITTING = 'transmitting'
class pygissim.engine.WaitingRequest(request: ClientRequest, wait_start: int, service_time: int | None, latency: int | None, wait_mode: WaitMode, queue_time: int = 0)[source]

Bases: object

Wrapper class for handling a ClientRequest in a MultiQueue in preparation for processing a step of the request.

The wait_mode is used for later summarization: - TRANSMITTING: a Connection is processing this request. - PROCESSSING: a ComputeNode is processing this request. - QUEUEING: the request is in a queue, waiting for a channel.

Parameters:

  • request – The request to be wrapped.

  • wait_start – The simulation clock when the request was wrapped.

  • service_time – The service time for this step of the request. None is to support cases where the current step might be None.

  • latency – The latency time for this step of the request. None is supported if latency time is None or there is no current step.

  • wait_mode – The state of this WaitingRequest.

queue_ended(clock: int, wait_mode: WaitMode)[source]

The request is moving out of the queue and into a channel. The time spent in the queue is recorded, and the wait mode is updated to reflect the type of processor, either a Connection or a ComputeNode.

Parameters:

  • clock – The current simulation time.

  • wait_mode – The wait mode for this queue’s ServiceTimeCalculator

wait_end() → int | None[source]
Returns:

The simulation time when this request will be finished processing. None if queueing or service time is None.

class pygissim.engine.Workflow(name: str, desc: str, type: WorkflowType, definition: WorkflowDef, user_count: int = 0, productivity: int = 0, tph: int = 0)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a configuration of a WorkflowDef, with productivity stats. The configuration of the productivity will determine how frequently this Workflow is triggered.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive name.

  • desc – Additional descriptive text

  • definition – The workflow definition (chains, steps)

  • type – Whether this workflow’s transaction rate is calculated from numbers of users or tph.

  • user_count – The number of users. Only applies to WorkflowType.USER.

  • productivity – The number of transactions per minute per user. Only applies to WorkflowType.USER.

  • tph – The transactions per hour. Only applies to WorkflowType.TRANSACTIONAL.

calculate_next_event_time(clock: int) → int[source]

transaction_rate is in transactions per hour, while the time between events is in ms. This function calculates the time between transactions and then applies a normalized random factor which allows a more “natural” arrival of requests.

Parameters:

clock – The current simulation time.

Returns:

The next time this Workflow will execute.

create_client_requests(network: list[Connection], clock: int) → Tuple[Transaction, list[ClientRequest]][source]

When a transaction starts, each chain needs to be solved for. This will result in one or more ClientRequests.

Parameters:

  • network – The set of Connections that represent the network.

  • clock – The current simulation time.

is_valid() → bool[source]
Returns:

True if validate returns no messages.

transaction_rate() → int[source]
Returns:

The number of transactions per hour.

validate() → list[ValidationMessage][source]

Tests the transaction rate and the validity of the definition.

Returns:

A list of ValidationMessages. An empty list indicates the Workflow is valid.

class pygissim.engine.WorkflowChain(name: str, desc: str, steps: list[WorkflowDefStep], service_providers: dict[str, ServiceProvider], additional_client_step: WorkflowDefStep | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a series of steps that define the parts of a Workflow. Most Workflows will have more than one chain of steps that are independent from each other.

Example: a mobile WorkflowDef might specify (1) fetching features from a hosted service and (2) fetching basemap tiles.

Example WorkflowChain: ArcGIS Field Maps > Web Adaptor > Portal > AGS > Relational DataStore

all_required_service_types() → Set[str][source]

All of the service types specified by steps.

configured_service_types() → Set[str][source]

All of the service types specified by the configured dict of ServiceProvider.

is_valid() → bool[source]
Returns:

True if validate returns no messages.

Return type:

bool

missing_service_providers() → list[str][source]

The service types needed by the chain, but not available in the ServiceProviders.

service_provider_for_step(step: WorkflowDefStep) → ServiceProvider | None[source]
Returns:

The configured ServiceProvider that matches the service type of a step. Returns None if no ServiceProvider matches the service type of the step.

service_provider_for_step_at_index(index: int) → ServiceProvider | None[source]
Returns:

The configured ServiceProvider that matches the service type of the step at an index. Returns None for an invalid index or no configured ServiceProvider for the step.

update_client_step(client_step: WorkflowDefStep)[source]

Convenience method to replace the first step in the chain. Useful when multiple WorkflowChains differ only in their client.

Parameters:

client_step – The step that will replace the first step in this chain.

class pygissim.engine.WorkflowDefStep(name: str, description: str, service_type: str, service_time: int, chatter: int, request_size_kb: int, response_size_kb: int, data_source_type: DataSourceType, cache_pct: int)[source]

class pygissim.engine.WorkflowType(*values)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enumeration of workflow types.

  • USER indicates that transaction rates will be calculated from user counts and productivity.

  • TRANSACTIONAL indicates that transaction rates will be entered directly as transactions per hour.

TRANSACTIONAL = 'transactional'
USER = 'user'
class pygissim.engine.Zone(name: str, desc: str)[source]

Bases: object

Represents a network environment that can host ComputeNodes. A network is formed by Zones being connected by Connection s. Many of the functions below accept an ‘in_network’ parameter, which is the list of Connections, usually maintained by the pygissim.pygissim.Design in its ‘network’ property.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive name. Should be unique in a pygissim.pygissim.Design.

  • desc – Text that describes the Zone in more detail.

classmethod all_zones(in_network: list[Connection]) → Set[Zone][source]

Parameters:

in_network – The list of Connections representing a network.

Returns:

All unique Zones that the Connections reference.

Return type:

Set[Zone]

  • lat – the latency of the Connection, in millseconds (ms).

pygissim.engine.create_solution(chain: WorkflowChain, in_network: list[Connection]) → ClientRequestSolution[source]

Creates a ClientRequestSolution for one WorkflowChain.

This is a key part of pygissim! The request is solved by hopping from ServiceProvider to ServiceProvider.

  1. The request passes through the WorkflowChain in order

  2. The request passes back through the WorkflowChain in reverse order, back to the caller.

For every step, the request is processed by the ServiceProvider, and then may take zero or more network hops to get to the next ServiceProvider.

Parameters:

  • chain – The WorkflowChain that is being solved for.

  • in_network – The list of Connections that represent the network.

pygissim.engine.find_route(start: Zone, end: Zone, in_network: list[Connection]) → Route | None[source]

Finds a path through the network from one Zone to another.

Parameters:

  • start – The Zone to start finding from.

  • end – The Zone to find the shortest path to.

In_network:

The list of Connections that represents the network.

Returns:

The shortest route from start to end. Returns None if no route could be found.

pygissim.pygissim module

pygissim.py

The higher-level classes: Design and Simulator.

Uses the pygissim.engine extensively to build a simulation design and then run it.

class pygissim.pygissim.Design(name: str, desc: str, zones: list[Zone] | None = None, network: list[Connection] | None = None, services: dict[str, ServiceDef] | None = None, service_providers: list[ServiceProvider] | None = None, workflow_definitions: list[WorkflowDef] | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

The Design is the setup of the infrastructure (network, compute) and the workflows that define the system that is being simulated.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive name

  • desc – Additional descriptive text

  • network – The list of Connections that will represent the network

  • services – The dictionary of all known service types (keys) and ServiceDefs (values)

  • workflow_definitions – The workflows (chains, steps) that are defined in the design.

add_client_workflow(name: str, desc: str, wdef_name: str, users: int, productivity: int) → Workflow[source]

Convenience method to configure a USER Workflow from a named WorkflowDef in the Design.

Parameters:

  • name – The name of the new configured Workflow.

  • desc – Addtional descriptive text.

  • wdef_name – The name of the WorkflowDef that will define the new Workflow.

  • users – The number of users.

  • productivity – The number of transactions per minute per user.

Raises:

ValueError if wdef_name is not a known name of a WorkflowDef in the Design.

Returns:

The created Workflow.

add_compute(node: ComputeNode)[source]

Adds a ComputeNode to the Design. Will not allow a node with ComputeNodeType V_SERVER to be added, since virtual servers are added implicitly when their physical host is added.

Parameters:

node – The ComputeNode to add to the Design.

Raises:

TypeError if node.type is ComputeNodeType.V_SERVER

Convenience method to add a Connection to the design with an option to add the return Connection too.

  • add_reciprocal – If True, will add a second Connection to the Design, in the reciprocal direction.

print_validation_messages()[source]

Method to print out all validation messages in all components of the Design. Useful for debugging if Design.is_valid() is returning False.

provide_queues() → list[MultiQueue][source]

Calls provide_queue() on every ComputeNode and Connection in the Design.

Returns:

A list of all queues in the Design.

remove_compute(node: ComputeNode)[source]

Removes a ComputeNode from the Design. May have cascading effects, so internally this method calls update_service_providers() and update_workflow_definitions() because the removed ComputeNode could have been a node for a ServiceProvider.

Because of the above logic, this is the best way to remove a V_SERVER.

Parameters:

node – The ComputeNode to add to the Design.

remove_connection(conn: Connection)[source]

Convenience method to remove a Connection from the Design.

remove_service_provider(sp: ServiceProvider)[source]

Removes a ServiceProvider from the Design. May have cascading effects, so internally this method calls update_workflow_definitions() because the removed ServiceProvider could have been referenced in a WorkflowDef.

Parameters:

sp – The ServiceProvider to remove.

remove_servicedef(sd: ServiceDef)[source]

Removes a ServiceDef from the Design. May have cascading effects, so internally this method calls update_service_providers() and update_workflow_definitions() because the removed ServiceDef could have been a type for a ServiceProvider.

Parameters:

sd – The ServiceDef to remove.

remove_workflow(w: Workflow)[source]

Convenience method to remove a Workflow from the Design.

Raises:

ValueError if the Workflow does not exist in the Design.

remove_workflowdef(wdef: WorkflowDef)[source]

Removes a WorkflowDef from the Design. May have cascading effects, so internally this method calls update_configured_workflows() because the removed WorkflowDef could have been referenced in a Workflow.

Parameters:

wdef – The WorkflowDef to remove.

remove_zone(zone: Zone)[source]

Removes a Zone from the Design. Doing so can have cascading effects, so internally this method removes any Connections that touched this Zone and then calls update_service_providers() and update_workflow_definitions() because removing a Zone could have removed ComputeNodes.

Parameters:

zone – The Zone to remove.

update_configured_workflows()[source]

Function to be called if a change has been made that may invalidate one or more Workflows. Examples of changes that might do this:

  • A WorkflowDef has been removed.

update_service_providers()[source]

Function to be called if a change has been made that may invalidate one or more ServiceProviders. Examples of changes that might do this:

  • A ServiceDef has been removed

  • A ComputeNode has been removed

update_workflow_definitions()[source]

Function to be called if a change has been made that may invalidate one or more WorkflowDefs. Examples of changes that might do this:

  • A ServiceProvider has been removed.

validate() → list[ValidationMessage][source]

Method that evaluates the validity of the configuration of this Design.

Returns:

Messages indicating invalid configuration.

Return type:

list[ValidationMessage]

class pygissim.pygissim.Simulator(name: str, desc: str, design: Design | None = None)[source]

Bases: object

The Simulator is the functional part of pygissim. The Simulator takes the setup from a Design and runs it.

Parameters:

  • name – A descriptive name

  • desc – Additional descriptive text

  • design – A design to simulate. If not specified, an empty Design will be created.

active_requests() → list[WaitingRequest][source]
Returns:

A list of all requests in all queues.

advance_time_by(ms: int) → int[source]

Moves the Simulator clock forward by a number of milliseconds.

Parameters:

ms – The number of milliseconds to move the clock forward.

Returns:

The new Simulator clock.

Raises:

ValueError if ms is negative or zero.

advance_time_to(clock: int) → int[source]

Moves the Simulator clock forward to a specific future time.

Parameters:

clock – The future Simulator time to go to.

Returns:

The new Simulator clock (will be the same as the clock parameter passed)

Raises:

ValueError if the specified clock time is not after the current Simulator clock.

find_queue(st_calc: ServiceTimeCalculator) → MultiQueue | None[source]

Convenience method to find the MultiQueue that has a particular pygissim.engine.ComputeNode or pygissim.engine.Connection as its pygissim.engine.ServiceTimeCalculator.

Parameters:

st_calc – The ComputeNode or Connection.

Returns:

The MultiQueue that has st_calc as its service time calculator. Returns None if no queue is found.

gather_queue_metrics()[source]

Gathers a pygissim.engine.QueueMetric from every queue and stores it in queue_metrics.

next_event_time() → int | None[source]

If the simulator is started or there are existing requests in the system, then there will be a clock value in the future when the next event happens, such as a new Transaction starting or a request being finished processing or passing through a Connection.

Returns:

The clock time when the next thing happens. Returns None if there are no forecast events.

reset()[source]

Resets the clock and all artifacts from previous run(s). Is called by start().

start()[source]

Puts the Simulator into a mode where time can be moved forward and requests will be generated.

Normal process for running the Simulator:

  1. start()

  2. advance_time_by() or advance_time_to()

  3. stop()

The simulator time does not advance by itself, code to run the simulator might look like:

sim.start()
for i in range(1,500):
    sim.advance_time_by(500)
    sim.gather_queue_metrics()
sim.stop()
Raises:

ValueError if the Design is None or the Design is not valid.

stop()[source]

Stops the Simulator from generating new requests. Time can still be advanced, and existing requests will continue to be processed until they are all finished.
